questions.question: Which verb class shifts to Ergative-Absolutive alignment in Series II?
questions.explanation: Only Class I (Transitive) verbs shift to Ergative-Absolutive alignment in Series II. This is the key feature of Georgian split-ergativity.

questions.question: What case alignment does Class II use in Series II?
questions.explanation: Class II (Intransitive) verbs maintain Nominative case in ALL series - they never shift to Ergative.

questions.question: What is the systematic process for conjugating a verb?

options.text: 1) Identify Class, 2) Determine Series, 3) Predict Alignment, 4) Apply Conjugation, 5) Verify

questions.explanation: The systematic 5-step process allows you to conjugate any verb in any tense methodically.

questions.question: Complete: მე _____ კატა (I saw the cat - should use Series II)
questions.explanation: ვნახე is Series II (Aorist) with Ergative-Absolutive alignment (cat is now Nominative/Absolutive without case marker).

questions.question: Match each Class-Series combination to its alignment in Series II
questions.explanation: In Series II: Class I shifts to Ergative-Absolutive, Class II stays Nominative, Class IV stays Dative-Nominative.

questions.question: What is the Perfect (Series III) case alignment for Class I verbs?
questions.explanation: Class I verbs shift BACK to Nominative-Accusative in Series III (Perfect), returning to the Series I pattern.

questions.question: In the sentence 'როცა ჩავედი, უკვე დავასრულედმიყავ საშინაოდრო' (When I arrived, I had already finished homework), which tense is 'დავასრულედმიყავ'?
questions.explanation: წინადროიტალური (Pluperfect) is Series III Perfect, showing the homework was finished BEFORE the arrival (past before past).

questions.question: Complete: მე კატას _____ (I have seen the cat - Series III)
questions.explanation: ვნახიყავ is Series III Perfect, and the case alignment shifts BACK to Nominative-Accusative (კატას is Dative again).

questions.question: What is the key insight about the Georgian verb system?

options.text: Only Class I shifts alignment in Series II; others stay stable
All verbs use the same conjugation

questions.explanation: The systematic pattern is that only Class I shifts to Ergative in Series II. All other classes maintain their alignment across all series.

questions.question: After mastering this matrix, what can you do?

options.text: Systematically conjugate ANY verb in ANY tense

questions.explanation: Mastering the matrix gives you systematic mastery - you can predict and conjugate any verb form using the systematic approach.
